howItWorks.title: How the Grade Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Final Grade = Sum of (Category Score x Category Weight) / 100
howItWorks.explanation: The grade calculator uses the weighted average principle, where each score is multiplied by its assigned weight and the results are summed to obtain the final grade. This reflects the relative importance of each assessment component.
steps: Enter the name of each assessment category (e.g., assignments, quizzes, final exam)
Specify the relative weight for each category (total must equal 100%)
Enter the score you received in each category
The calculator will automatically compute your final grade
You can add a target grade to see what you need on the final exam

useCases: Calculate your expected final grade before the semester ends
Determine the required score on the final exam to achieve your goal
Compare different academic performance scenarios
Plan effort distribution among different courses
seoTips: Use the calculator at the beginning of the semester to set realistic goals
Make sure to enter the correct weights according to your syllabus
Review your grades regularly to track your progress
Use the 'what-if' feature to explore different possibilities
commonMistakes: Not ensuring that the sum of weights equals 100%
Confusing absolute scores with percentages
Forgetting to update grades after each assessment
Not accounting for all assessment components

faqs.question: How do I calculate my grade if the weights are unknown?
faqs.answer: If you don't know the weights, you can assume equal weights for all categories, or refer to your course syllabus for the correct distribution.

faqs.question: Can I use the calculator for multiple courses?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can use the calculator separately for each course, as weights and categories may differ from course to course.

faqs.question: What should I do if the required grade is over 100%?
faqs.answer: This means the goal is unachievable. You may need to revise your expectations or focus on improving grades in other categories.

faqs.question: How does the calculator handle extra credit?
faqs.answer: You can enter scores exceeding 100% in categories that allow it, and the calculator will compute the result accordingly.

gpa.title: GPA Calculator
gpa.description: Calculate your semester and cumulative Grade Point Average (GPA) easily.
gpa.explanation: GPA is calculated by multiplying each course grade point by its credit hours, then dividing the total grade points by the total credit hours.

errors.invalid_current_gpa: Current GPA cannot exceed the selected scale
errors.no_courses: Please add at least one course

howItWorks.title: How the GPA Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: GPA = Sum of (Course Grade Points x Credits) / Total Credits
howItWorks.explanation: The cumulative GPA is calculated by converting each letter grade to grade points (e.g., A=4.0, B=3.0), then multiplying each course's grade points by its credit hours, and finally dividing the sum by the total credits.
steps: Select the GPA scale used by your institution (4.0 or 5.0)
Enter your current cumulative GPA and credit hours (optional)
Add your current semester courses with their grades and credits
The semester and new cumulative GPA will be displayed automatically

useCases: Calculate semester and cumulative GPA for academic planning
Understand the impact of current semester grades on cumulative GPA
Plan for honors or dean's list achievement
Identify courses that need improvement to raise GPA
seoTips: Keep an accurate record of all your courses and grades
Use the calculator before registration to see the impact of new courses
Compare different scenarios for expected grades
Review graduation and major requirements regularly
commonMistakes: Confusing the 4.0 scale with the 5.0 scale
Not accounting for all previous credit hours
Entering percentage grades instead of letter grades
Forgetting repeated or transferred courses

faqs.question: What is the difference between semester GPA and cumulative GPA?
faqs.answer: Semester GPA is calculated for current semester courses only, while cumulative GPA includes all courses since the start of your academic career.

faqs.question: How do I calculate GPA if I repeated a course?
faqs.answer: This depends on your institution's policy. Some universities count only the higher grade, while others average both attempts.

faqs.question: Do Pass/Fail courses affect GPA?
faqs.answer: Typically, Pass/Fail courses do not affect the cumulative GPA, but they may count toward credit hours.

faqs.question: How can I raise my cumulative GPA?
faqs.answer: Focus on courses with more credit hours, take advantage of course repeat opportunities, and plan ahead for future semesters.

howItWorks.title: How the Final Grade Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Required Score = (Target - Current x (1 - Weight)) / Weight
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the score you need on the final exam to reach your target grade, based on your current grade and the weight of the final exam.
steps: Enter your current grade in the course (before the final exam)
Specify your target final grade
Enter the weight of the final exam as a percentage of the total grade
The required final exam score will be displayed

useCases: Plan for final exams and know the minimum required score
Prioritize study time among different courses
Determine if a certain grade is achievable before the exam
Manage expectations and reduce exam stress
seoTips: Use the calculator weeks before the exam for proper planning
Try multiple scenarios for different target grades
Verify the final exam weight from your course syllabus
Share results with study groups for mutual motivation
commonMistakes: Entering the exam weight incorrectly
Not updating the current grade after each assessment
Ignoring results when the required score is too high
Relying entirely on the final exam without working during the semester

faqs.question: What if the required score is over 100%?
faqs.answer: This means achieving the goal is mathematically impossible. You may need to lower your expectations or look for extra credit opportunities.

faqs.question: Can I use the calculator for any grading system?
faqs.answer: Yes, as long as you know your current grade and the final exam weight, the calculator works with any system.

faqs.question: How do I calculate my current grade?
faqs.answer: Sum all previous assessment scores multiplied by their weights, then divide by the sum of the weights.

attendance.title: Attendance Calculator
attendance.description: Track your class attendance and see how many more classes you can miss.
attendance.result_placeholder: Enter your class details to see your attendance status.

messages.above_target: You can miss {{count}} more classes while staying above your target.
messages.below_target: You need to attend {{count}} more classes to reach your target.
messages.exact_target: You are exactly at your target attendance percentage.

errors.invalid_total: Total classes must be greater than 0
errors.invalid_attended: Attended classes cannot exceed total classes
errors.invalid_target: Target percentage must be between 1 and 100

howItWorks.title: How the Attendance Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Attendance Percentage = (Classes Attended / Total Classes) x 100
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your current attendance percentage and determines how many classes you can miss while maintaining your target percentage.
steps: Enter the total number of classes in the course
Enter the number of classes you have attended
Set your target attendance percentage (usually 75% or 80%)
Your current percentage and allowed absences will be displayed

useCases: Know how many absences are allowed before being barred
Plan for absences in emergency situations
Track attendance across multiple courses simultaneously
Ensure you meet attendance requirements for exams
seoTips: Record your attendance regularly to avoid surprises
Learn the attendance policy for each course
Keep a safety margin for unexpected emergencies
Communicate with instructors in case of mandatory absences
commonMistakes: Not accounting for cancelled or postponed classes
Confusing different sessions of the same course
Forgetting to sign attendance in official records
Relying on memory instead of regular tracking

faqs.question: What is the typical required attendance percentage?
faqs.answer: It varies by institution and course, but common requirements are 75% or 80%. Check your university's policy.

faqs.question: Does being late count as an absence?
faqs.answer: It depends on the instructor's policy. Some count significant lateness as half an absence or a full absence.

faqs.question: What happens if I exceed the allowed absences?
faqs.answer: Typically, you may be barred from the final exam or have points deducted. Check your institution's regulations.

semester.title: Semester Grade Calculator
semester.description: Calculate your weighted average for multiple courses in a semester.
semester.result_placeholder: Add your courses to calculate your semester average.

errors.no_courses: Please add at least one course

howItWorks.title: How the Semester Grade Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Average = Sum of (Course Grade x Credits) / Total Credits
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the weighted average of your grades for the semester, taking into account the credit hours for each course.
steps: Add each course with its name for organization
Enter the percentage grade for each course
Specify the credit hours for each course
The calculator will compute the weighted average and letter grade

useCases: Calculate semester average before official results are released
Compare performance across different semesters
Plan for grade improvement in future semesters
Understand the impact of each course on overall average
seoTips: Enter all courses even if their grades are low
Use the calculator to experiment with grade improvement scenarios
Compare expected average with the required average for your goals
Keep a record of all previous semester averages
commonMistakes: Entering letter grades instead of percentages
Not distinguishing between lecture and lab credits
Forgetting certain courses when calculating
Confusing course credits with assessment weights

faqs.question: What is the difference between semester average and cumulative GPA?
faqs.answer: Semester average is calculated for one semester, while cumulative GPA combines all semesters since the start of study.

faqs.question: Do elective courses affect the average?
faqs.answer: Yes, all officially registered courses affect the average according to their credit hours.

faqs.question: How do I calculate the average for courses without numerical grades?
faqs.answer: Convert letter grades to percentages (e.g., A=95%, B=85%) and then enter them.

test_score.title: Test Score Calculator
test_score.description: Calculate your test percentage and letter grade easily.
test_score.result_placeholder: Enter the number of questions and mistakes to see your score.

errors.invalid_total: Total questions must be greater than 0
errors.invalid_wrong: Wrong answers cannot exceed total questions

howItWorks.title: How the Test Score Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Percentage = ((Total Questions - Wrong Answers) / Total Questions) x 100
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your percentage score and converts it to a letter grade based on the total number of questions and wrong answers.
steps: Enter the total number of test questions
Enter the number of wrong answers
The percentage and letter grade will be displayed automatically
You can view the grading scale being used

useCases: Quickly calculate test scores after reviewing answers
Know the expected letter grade before official results
Evaluate performance on practice tests
Compare scores across multiple tests
seoTips: Make sure to count wrong answers accurately
Use the calculator for practice tests to track improvement
Compare your results with the class average
Identify question types you get wrong most often
commonMistakes: Confusing skipped questions with wrong answers
Not accounting for multi-part questions correctly
Forgetting questions with different point values
Using an incorrect grading scale

faqs.question: How do I calculate the score if questions have different point values?
faqs.answer: This calculator assumes equal points. For different values, manually sum the points earned and divide by the total possible points.

faqs.question: What grading scale is used?
Are unanswered questions counted as wrong?
faqs.answer: Yes, in most tests, unanswered questions are counted as incorrect answers.

assignment_tracker.title: Assignment Tracker
assignment_tracker.description: Keep track of your school assignments and deadlines.
assignment_tracker.no_assignments: No assignments added yet. Start by adding one above!
assignment_tracker.tip_1: Break large projects into smaller, manageable tasks.
assignment_tracker.tip_2: Prioritize assignments by their due dates and weights.
assignment_tracker.tip_3: Check off completed tasks to stay motivated.

howItWorks.title: How the Assignment Tracker Works
howItWorks.formula: Completion Rate = (Completed Assignments / Total Assignments) x 100
howItWorks.explanation: This tracker helps you organize your assignments and tasks in one place, while monitoring deadlines and completion rate.
steps: Add each assignment or task with the course name
Set the due date for each assignment
Mark assignments as complete when finished
Track your overall completion rate

useCases: Organize all assignments and projects in one place
Avoid forgetting important deadlines
Track progress on long-term projects
Manage time across different courses
seoTips: Add assignments immediately when you receive them
Break large projects into sub-tasks with interim deadlines
Review your list daily in the morning and evening
Use colors or symbols to distinguish priorities
commonMistakes: Not updating the list regularly
Adding tasks that are too general without details
Ignoring small tasks that accumulate
Not setting realistic due dates

faqs.question: How do I prioritize assignments?
faqs.answer: Prioritize by: 1) Nearest deadline, 2) Highest weight in grade, 3) Most complex requiring more time.

faqs.question: What should I do when assignments pile up?
faqs.answer: Identify the most important and urgent, communicate with instructors if needed, and ask classmates for help.

faqs.question: Should I track small assignments?
faqs.answer: Yes, small assignments add up and affect your grade. Track everything for better organization.

study_time.title: Study Time Calculator
study_time.description: Calculate recommended study hours based on your course load.
study_time.recommendation_text: Based on {{hours}} hours of weekly study and a {{difficulty}} difficulty level, we recommend taking short breaks every 50 minutes to maintain focus.
study_time.result_placeholder: Enter your course details to see a study plan.

howItWorks.title: How the Study Time Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Study Hours = Credit Hours x Difficulty Factor x 2-3
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates optimal study time based on credit hours and course difficulty level, taking into account available study days.
steps: Enter your total weekly credit hours
Specify the number of days available for study
Select the average difficulty level of your courses
Get a daily and weekly study plan

useCases: Create a realistic and balanced study schedule
Distribute time among different courses
Plan for exam periods
Balance studying with other activities
seoTips: Start with difficult subjects when your energy is high
Take short breaks every 45-50 minutes
Vary your study methods
Review your plan weekly and adjust as needed
commonMistakes: Overestimating available study time
Not accounting for commute and daily activities
Studying all subjects with the same intensity
Ignoring the need for rest and recreation

faqs.question: How many study hours per credit hour?
faqs.answer: The general rule is 2-3 study hours per credit hour, increasing for difficult courses.

faqs.question: Is long studying better than short repeated sessions?
faqs.answer: Short, repeated sessions are more effective. Sessions of 45-90 minutes with breaks are better for memory.

faqs.question: How do I deal with procrastination?
faqs.answer: Start with a small 5-minute task, use the Pomodoro technique, and remove distractions from your environment.

reading_speed.title: Reading Speed Calculator
reading_speed.description: Measure your reading speed and estimate reading time.
reading_speed.timer_hint: Read a sample text and stop the timer when done
reading_speed.level_slow: You read at a deliberate pace, which is great for deep comprehension and technical material.
reading_speed.level_average: You read at an average speed (200-300 WPM). This is a standard pace for general reading.
reading_speed.level_fast: You are a fast reader! This pace is excellent for scanning and general information gathering.
reading_speed.result_placeholder: Use the timer or enter data manually to calculate your speed.

howItWorks.title: How the Reading Speed Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Reading Speed (WPM) = Number of Words / Time in Minutes
howItWorks.explanation: This tool measures your reading speed in Words Per Minute (WPM) and estimates the time needed to read texts of various lengths.
steps: Press the start button and read a specific text
Press the stop button when finished
Enter the number of words you read
Get your speed and estimated reading times

useCases: Measure current reading speed for improvement
Estimate reading time for books and articles
Plan study and review time
Compare reading speed before and after training
seoTips: Measure your speed with texts of varying difficulty
Practice speed reading techniques regularly
Balance speed with comprehension
Use results to plan your reading schedule
commonMistakes: Reading aloud or moving lips (slows reading)
Going back and re-reading sentences frequently
Reading word by word instead of groups
Ignoring comprehension in favor of speed

faqs.question: What is a normal reading speed?
faqs.answer: The average is 200-300 words/minute. Fast readers reach 400-600, and experts may exceed 1000.

faqs.question: How can I increase my reading speed?
faqs.answer: Use your finger or a pen as a guide, stop subvocalizing, expand your peripheral vision, and practice daily.

faqs.question: Does high speed affect comprehension?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. With practice, you can increase speed while maintaining or improving comprehension.
